lead_paragraph: Officials say the Islamic State has lost thousands of fighters, millions of dollars and much territory, but the airstrikes have done little to stop the group’s expansion elsewhere.

byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg and Helene Cooper reported from Washington, and Nicholas Kulish from New York. Omar Al-Jawoshy contributed reporting from Baghdad, and an employee of The New York Times from Erbil, Iraq.
byline.original: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG, HELENE COOPER and NICHOLAS KULISH

headline.print_headline: ISIS Taking Hits on Front Lines and Cash Flow
headline.main: ISIS Expands Reach Despite Military and Financial Setbacks

snippet: Officials say the Islamic State has lost thousands of fighters, millions of dollars and much territory, but the airstrikes have done little to stop the group’s expansion elsewhere.
abstract: American and foreign forces have dealt significant blows to Islamic State, in terms of deaths, finances and territory, but attacks outside Iraq and Syria point to group's continued expansion; danger posed by small and home-grown terrorist cells requires that United States and allies carry out more complex, and probably lengthy, fight.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
